title: CS506: Data Wrangling and Management
text:
Preface
Welcome to CS506: Data Wrangling and Management. This course introduces graduate students to data wrangling and management using R and the Tidyverse ecosystem. Students will learn to import, manipulate, clean, and visualize data with a strong emphasis on practical applications and reproducible workflows. The course will utilize the free textbook R for Data Science by Hadley Wickham and Garrett Grolemund.
Course Objectives: Upon successful completion of the course, students will be able to:
Textbook: R for Data Science by Hadley Wickham & Garrett Grolemund (Available for free: https://r4ds.hadley.nz/)
Software Requirements:

title: CS506: Data Wrangling and Management
text:
Footnotes

This is a Quarto book. To learn more about Quarto books visit https://quarto.org/docs/books.
This website is published using Github Pages.

title: 2  Introduction to R and RStudio
text:
2.1 Learning Objectives
By the end of this chapter, you should be able to:
R is a programming language designed for data analysis.RStudio is an Integrated Development Environment (IDE) that makes working with R easier.
crumbs: 2  Introduction to R and RStudio

title: 2  Introduction to R and RStudio
text:
Install and open R and RStudio

Navigate the four-pane layout of RStudio

Create and run R scripts

Understand the differences between the console, script editor, and environment

Execute basic R operations and understand data types

Install and load R packages
## Getting Started



2.1.1 Installing R and RStudio

Install R: https://cran.r-project.org/

Install RStudio: https://posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop/


Once you open RStudio, you’ll see four panes:


Console – for running code interactively


Source – to write and save scripts


Environment/History – to view and manage objects


Files/Plots/Packages/Help/Viewer – navigation and visualization tools
crumbs: 2  Introduction to R and RStudio

title: 2  Introduction to R and RStudio
text:
2.2 Basic R Concepts

2.2.1 Variables and Assignments

x <- 5
y <- 10
z <- x + y
z

[1] 15



2.2.2 Vectors and Functions

ages <- c(25, 30, 35, 40)
mean(ages)

[1] 32.5

sd(ages)

[1] 6.454972



2.2.3 Data Frames

name <- c("Alice", "Bob", "Charlie")
age <- c(25, 30, 35)
student_data <- data.frame(name, age)
student_data

     name age
1   Alice  25
2     Bob  30
3 Charlie  35



2.2.4 Inspecting Data

str(student_data)

'data.frame':   3 obs. of  2 variables:
 $ name: chr  "Alice" "Bob" "Charlie"
 $ age : num  25 30 35

summary(student_data)

     name                age      
 Length:3           Min.   :25.0  
 Class :character   1st Qu.:27.5  
 Mode  :character   Median :30.0  
                    Mean   :30.0  
                    3rd Qu.:32.5  
                    Max.   :35.0  

head(student_data)

     name age
1   Alice  25
2     Bob  30
3 Charlie  35



2.2.5 Comments and Help

# This is a comment
?mean  # Help for the mean function


2.2.6 Using Scripts and Console

Write your code in the script editor and run lines with Ctrl+Enter (Cmd+Enter on Mac)
Save your work with .R extensions
Use the Console for quick exploration

2.2.7 Insalling and Loading Packages
#Run this manually in the Console, not in the book install.packages(“tidyverse”)

2.2.8 Practice Exercises

Create a script that assigns two numbers and prints their sum
Create a vector of Celsius temperatures and convert to Fahrenheit
Create a data frame with columns: name, age, major


# Exercise 1
a <- 15
b <- 20
a + b

[1] 35

# Exercise 2
celsius <- c(0, 10, 20)
fahrenheit <- celsius * 9/5 + 32
fahrenheit

[1] 32 50 68

# Exercise 3
students <- data.frame(
  name = c("Lily", "Mark", "Tom"),
  age = c(21, 22, 23),
  major = c("Biology", "Math", "History")
)
str(students)

'data.frame':   3 obs. of  3 variables:
 $ name : chr  "Lily" "Mark" "Tom"
 $ age  : num  21 22 23
 $ major: chr  "Biology" "Math" "History"



2.2.9 Next Steps
Now that you can run R scripts and explore objects, you’ll learn how to load and reshape real data using the tidyverse in the next chapter.
crumbs: 2  Introduction to R and RStudio

By the end of this chapter, you should be able to:

title: 3  Tidy Data and the Tidyverse
text:
Define “tidy data” and explain why it’s important

Load the Tidyverse and understand the role of its core packages

Import a dataset using readr::read_csv()

Use glimpse(), str(), and summary() to explore data
crumbs: 3  Tidy Data and the Tidyverse

title: 3  Tidy Data and the Tidyverse
text:
3.2 Key Concepts

Tidy data: one row per observation, one column per variable
Install and load

title: 3  Tidy Data and the Tidyverse
text:
3.2 What is Tidy Data?
Tidy data follows three key principles (from R for Data Science):

Each variable forms a column

Each observation forms a row

Each type of observational unit forms a table

Tidy data makes it easier to manipulate, visualize, and model data using consistent, reproducible tools.
crumbs: 3  Tidy Data and the Tidyverse

title: 3  Tidy Data and the Tidyverse
text:
3.3 What is the Tidyverse?
The Tidyverse is a collection of R packages designed for data science. It includes:


Package
Purpose



ggplot2
Data visualization


dplyr
Data manipulation


tidyr
Data reshaping


readr
Reading data


purrr
Functional programming


tibble
Modern data frames


stringr
String manipulation


forcats
Factor handling



Install and load the full tidyverse:

# Run this in the Console if you haven't installed yet
# install.packages("tidyverse")


library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.2     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.4     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors
crumbs: 3  Tidy Data and the Tidyverse

title: 3  Tidy Data and the Tidyverse
section: 3.4 Example: Reading in Data with readr
text:
3.4 Example: Reading in Data with readr


# Built-in example from the readr package
library(readr)

heights <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/hadley/r4ds/refs/heads/main/data/heights.csv")

Rows: 1192 Columns: 6
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (2): sex, race
dbl (4): earn, height, ed, age

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

glimpse(heights)

Rows: 1,192
Columns: 6
$ earn   <dbl> 50000, 60000, 30000, 50000, 51000, 9000, 29000, 32000, 2000, 27…
$ height <dbl> 74.42444, 65.53754, 63.62920, 63.10856, 63.40248, 64.39951, 61.…
$ sex    <chr> "male", "female", "female", "female", "female", "female", "fema…
$ ed     <dbl> 16, 16, 16, 16, 17, 15, 12, 17, 15, 12, 16, 11, 12, 12, 16, 12,…
$ age    <dbl> 45, 58, 29, 91, 39, 26, 49, 46, 21, 26, 65, 34, 27, 51, 35, 58,…
$ race   <chr> "white", "white", "white", "other", "white", "white", "white", …


read_csv() is faster and more predictable than base R’s read.csv(). It does not convert strings to factors and returns a tibble by default.
crumbs: 3  Tidy Data and the Tidyverse

title: 3  Tidy Data and the Tidyverse
text:
3.5 Exploring a Dataset

# Inspecting data structure
head(heights)

# A tibble: 6 × 6
   earn height sex       ed   age race 
  <dbl>  <dbl> <chr>  <dbl> <dbl> <chr>
1 50000   74.4 male      16    45 white
2 60000   65.5 female    16    58 white
3 30000   63.6 female    16    29 white
4 50000   63.1 female    16    91 other
5 51000   63.4 female    17    39 white
6  9000   64.4 female    15    26 white

str(heights)

spc_tbl_ [1,192 × 6] (S3: spec_tbl_df/tbl_df/tbl/data.frame)
 $ earn  : num [1:1192] 50000 60000 30000 50000 51000 9000 29000 32000 2000 27000 ...
 $ height: num [1:1192] 74.4 65.5 63.6 63.1 63.4 ...
 $ sex   : chr [1:1192] "male" "female" "female" "female" ...
 $ ed    : num [1:1192] 16 16 16 16 17 15 12 17 15 12 ...
 $ age   : num [1:1192] 45 58 29 91 39 26 49 46 21 26 ...
 $ race  : chr [1:1192] "white" "white" "white" "other" ...
 - attr(*, "spec")=
  .. cols(
  ..   earn = col_double(),
  ..   height = col_double(),
  ..   sex = col_character(),
  ..   ed = col_double(),
  ..   age = col_double(),
  ..   race = col_character()
  .. )
 - attr(*, "problems")=<externalptr> 

summary(heights)

      earn            height          sex                  ed      
 Min.   :   200   Min.   :57.50   Length:1192        Min.   : 3.0  
 1st Qu.: 10000   1st Qu.:64.01   Class :character   1st Qu.:12.0  
 Median : 20000   Median :66.45   Mode  :character   Median :13.0  
 Mean   : 23155   Mean   :66.92                      Mean   :13.5  
 3rd Qu.: 30000   3rd Qu.:69.85                      3rd Qu.:16.0  
 Max.   :200000   Max.   :77.05                      Max.   :18.0  
      age            race          
 Min.   :18.00   Length:1192       
 1st Qu.:29.00   Class :character  
 Median :38.00   Mode  :character  
 Mean   :41.38                     
 3rd Qu.:51.00                     
 Max.   :91.00                     


You can also use View(heights) to open a spreadsheet-like viewer in RStudio (note: this won’t work when rendering a book).
crumbs: 3  Tidy Data and the Tidyverse

title: 3  Tidy Data and the Tidyverse
text:
3.6 Tibbles verssus Data Frames
Tibbles are a modern version of data frames that:

Do not convert strings to factors
Have cleaner printing behavior
Work better with tidyverse functions


df_base <- data.frame(x = 1:3, y = letters[1:3])
df_tibble <- tibble(x = 1:3, y = letters[1:3])

df_base

  x y
1 1 a
2 2 b
3 3 c

df_tibble

# A tibble: 3 × 2
      x y    
  <int> <chr>
1     1 a    
2     2 b    
3     3 c
crumbs: 3  Tidy Data and the Tidyverse

title: 3  Tidy Data and the Tidyverse
text:
3.7 Practice Exercises

Use read_csv() to import the Palmer Penguins dataset:


URL: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/allisonhorst/palmerpenguins/master/inst/extdata/penguins.csv


Use glimpse() to inspect the structure of the data.
What do you notice about the column types? Which ones are characters, doubles, or factors?


penguins <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/allisonhorst/palmerpenguins/master/inst/extdata/penguins.csv")

Rows: 344 Columns: 8
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (3): species, island, sex
dbl (5): bill_length_mm, bill_depth_mm, flipper_length_mm, body_mass_g, year

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

glimpse(penguins)

Rows: 344
Columns: 8
$ species           <chr> "Adelie", "Adelie", "Adelie", "Adelie", "Adelie", "A…
$ island            <chr> "Torgersen", "Torgersen", "Torgersen", "Torgersen", …
$ bill_length_mm    <dbl> 39.1, 39.5, 40.3, NA, 36.7, 39.3, 38.9, 39.2, 34.1, …
$ bill_depth_mm     <dbl> 18.7, 17.4, 18.0, NA, 19.3, 20.6, 17.8, 19.6, 18.1, …
$ flipper_length_mm <dbl> 181, 186, 195, NA, 193, 190, 181, 195, 193, 190, 186…
$ body_mass_g       <dbl> 3750, 3800, 3250, NA, 3450, 3650, 3625, 4675, 3475, …
$ sex               <chr> "male", "female", "female", NA, "female", "male", "f…
$ year              <dbl> 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007…
crumbs: 3  Tidy Data and the Tidyverse

title: 3  Tidy Data and the Tidyverse
text:
3.8 Summary

Tidy data format is foundational for data science in R
The tidyverse packages are designed to work together

read_csv() from readr is you go-to function for reading flat files
Always explore dat awith glimpse(), str(), and summary()
crumbs: 3  Tidy Data and the Tidyverse

title: 3  Tidy Data and the Tidyverse
text:
3.9 Next Steps
In the next chapter, we’ll learn how to filter, select, and transform data using dplyr — the primary grammar of data manipulation in the tidyverse.
crumbs: 3  Tidy Data and the Tidyverse
